name: Granite
funFact: Forms from slowly cooled magma deep underground.

name: Basalt
funFact: Makes up most of the ocean floor.

name: Obsidian
funFact: Cools so quickly that crystals don’t form.

name: Pumice
funFact: Can float on water due to trapped gas bubbles.

name: Andesite
funFact: Common in volcanic arcs above subduction zones.

name: Diorite
funFact: Used by ancient civilizations for sculpture.

name: Rhyolite
funFact: Has the same composition as granite but cools faster.

name: Gabbro
funFact: Forms deep beneath the Earth's surface.

name: Scoria
funFact: Often used in landscaping and drainage.

name: Pegmatite
funFact: Can contain rare minerals like tourmaline and beryl.

name: Sandstone
funFact: Formed from compacted sand particles.

name: Shale
funFact: Often contains fossils and splits easily into layers.

name: Limestone
funFact: Often formed from marine organisms’ shells.

name: Conglomerate
funFact: Contains rounded pebbles cemented together.

name: Breccia
funFact: Similar to conglomerate but with angular fragments.

name: Chalk
funFact: Made from microscopic marine plankton.

name: Dolomite
funFact: Similar to limestone but contains magnesium.

name: Siltstone
funFact: Formed from silt-sized particles in calm water.

name: Coal
funFact: Formed from ancient plant material in swamps.

name: Gypsum
funFact: Forms from evaporated saline water.

name: Marble
funFact: Formed from limestone under heat and pressure.

name: Slate
funFact: Derived from shale; splits into flat sheets.

name: Schist
funFact: Contains visible mica flakes.

name: Gneiss
funFact: Shows distinct foliation from intense pressure.

name: Quartzite
funFact: Formed from sandstone under heat and pressure.

name: Phyllite
funFact: Between slate and schist in metamorphic grade.

name: Serpentinite
funFact: Formed from ultramafic rocks in subduction zones.

name: Hornfels
funFact: Forms from contact metamorphism near magma.

name: Amphibolite
funFact: Forms from basalt or gabbro under high pressure and temperature.

name: Eclogite
funFact: Forms deep in subduction zones and contains garnet and pyroxene.
